title: Isaiah Chapter 27 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Isaiah chapter 27 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Isaiah Chapter 27 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Isaiah Chapter 27.

questions.question: Who shall the LORD punish with his great and strong sword in that day?
questions.correctAnswer: Leviathan the piercing serpent
questions.explanation: Isaiah 27:1 states that the LORD shall punish leviathan the piercing serpent with his sore and great and strong sword.

questions.question: What is described as a 'vineyard of red wine' in Isaiah 27?
questions.correctAnswer: Her
questions.explanation: Isaiah 27:2 says, 'In that day sing ye unto her, A vineyard of red wine,' referring to 'her'.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 27:3, how often will the LORD water the vineyard?
questions.correctAnswer: Every moment
questions.explanation: Isaiah 27:3 states, 'I will water it every moment: lest any hurt it, I will keep it night and day.'

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 27:4 says that fury is in the LORD's heart.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 27:4 clearly states, 'Fury is not in me', indicating the LORD does not have fury.

questions.question: What does the LORD say about making peace in Isaiah 27:5?
options: Let him take hold of my strength, and he shall make peace with me
Peace will come through battle only
questions.correctAnswer: Let him take hold of my strength, and he shall make peace with me
questions.explanation: Isaiah 27:5 says, 'Or let him take hold of my strength, that he may make peace with me; and he shall make peace with me.'

questions.question: Who shall blossom and bud and fill the face of the world with fruit?
questions.correctAnswer: Israel
questions.explanation: Isaiah 27:6 states, 'Israel shall blossom and bud, and fill the face of the world with fruit.'

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 27:7 questions if the LORD was slain like those he smote.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 27:7 asks, 'Hath he smitten him, as he smote those that smote him? or is he slain according to the slaughter of them that are slain by him?'

questions.question: What will happen to the stones of the altar according to Isaiah 27:9?
options: They shall be beaten as chalkstones
questions.correctAnswer: They shall be beaten as chalkstones
questions.explanation: Isaiah 27:9 states, 'when he maketh all the stones of the altar as chalkstones that are beaten in sunder.'

questions.question: Complete this verse from Isaiah 27:10: 'Yet the defenced city shall be desolate, and the habitation forsaken, and left like a ________.'
questions.correctAnswer: wilderness
questions.explanation: Isaiah 27:10 says the habitation will be 'left like a wilderness.'

questions.question: What do the women do to the withered boughs in Isaiah 27:11?
questions.correctAnswer: Set them on fire
questions.explanation: Isaiah 27:11 states, 'The women come, and set them on fire.'

questions.question: According to Isaiah 27:12, how will the children of Israel be gathered?
questions.correctAnswer: One by one
questions.explanation: Isaiah 27:12 mentions, 'ye shall be gathered one by one, O ye children of Israel.'

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 27:13 says the great trumpet shall be blown in that day.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 27:13 clearly states, 'the great trumpet shall be blown.'

questions.question: Who will worship the LORD on the holy mount at Jerusalem according to Isaiah 27:13?
options: Those ready to perish in Assyria and the outcasts in Egypt
questions.correctAnswer: Those ready to perish in Assyria and the outcasts in Egypt
questions.explanation: Isaiah 27:13 says those ready to perish in Assyria and outcasts in Egypt shall worship the LORD in Jerusalem.

questions.question: In Isaiah 27:8, what does 'he' do to his rough wind in the day of the east wind?
questions.correctAnswer: He stayeth it
questions.explanation: Isaiah 27:8 says, 'he stayeth his rough wind in the day of the east wind.'

questions.question: According to Isaiah 27:9, what shall not stand up after the iniquity of Jacob is purged?
questions.correctAnswer: The groves and images
questions.explanation: Isaiah 27:9 notes that 'the groves and images shall not stand up' after the iniquity is purged.

medium.title: Isaiah Chapter 27 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Isaiah Chapter 27 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with fear and asks how God handles powerful enemies. Based on Isaiah 27:1, what biblical truth would you share?
options: God will punish and destroy evil powers like Leviathan
God ignores the enemies and lets them prevail
God makes peace with evil powers
God asks believers to fight Leviathan themselves
questions.correctAnswer: God will punish and destroy evil powers like Leviathan
questions.explanation: Isaiah 27:1 teaches that the LORD will use His strong sword to punish Leviathan, the piercing serpent, slaying the dragon in the sea, which symbolizes God's power to overcome evil forces. This encourages believers to trust God's protection and justice (Isaiah 27:1, 27:4, 27:5).

questions.question: How does Isaiah 27:3 illustrate God's care for His people and their spiritual growth?
options: God keeps and waters His vineyard continually to protect it
God leaves His vineyard unguarded at night
God punishes the vineyard for any mistakes
God relies on others to care for the vineyard
questions.correctAnswer: God keeps and waters His vineyard continually to protect it
questions.explanation: Verse 3 shows God's constant vigilance and provision, watering the vineyard every moment to prevent harm, symbolizing His personal care for His people’s spiritual well-being and growth (Isaiah 27:3, 27:6, 27:4).

questions.question: A believer is tempted to respond to opposition with anger. Based on Isaiah 27:4, what biblical virtue should you encourage?
options: Fury is not in God, so believers should respond with calm and patience
Fury is necessary to fight enemies
Anger is the best way to defend oneself
questions.correctAnswer: Fury is not in God, so believers should respond with calm and patience
questions.explanation: Isaiah 27:4 states that fury is not in God, highlighting that believers are called to trust God's strength over anger, promoting calmness and patience rather than rash reactions (Isaiah 27:4, 27:5, 27:6).

questions.question: What does Isaiah 27:6 teach about God's plan for His people and their witness to the world?
options: Israel shall blossom and fill the world with fruit, symbolizing spiritual growth and fruitful witness
Israel will remain isolated and fruitless
God will punish Israel without hope
Israel's growth depends on political power
questions.correctAnswer: Israel shall blossom and fill the world with fruit, symbolizing spiritual growth and fruitful witness
questions.explanation: Verse 6 shows God's promise that His people will take root, blossom, and fill the world with fruit, which encourages believers to grow spiritually and be effective witnesses (Isaiah 27:6, 27:3, 27:5).

questions.question: A fellow believer is doubting whether God will forgive their sins. How does Isaiah 27:9 provide assurance?
options: Iniquity will be purged and sins taken away by God's judgment
Forgiveness depends on human effort alone
God ignores sin and does not judge
questions.correctAnswer: Iniquity will be purged and sins taken away by God's judgment
questions.explanation: Isaiah 27:9 explains that God's purging of iniquity removes sin, symbolized by breaking altar stones, assuring believers of God's forgiveness when sins are addressed sincerely (Isaiah 27:9, 27:1, 27:13).

questions.question: According to Isaiah 27:12-13, what hope does God offer to His scattered people?
options: God will gather His people from various lands and restore their worship
God will leave His people permanently scattered
God will punish them without restoration
God’s restoration depends on human armies
questions.correctAnswer: God will gather His people from various lands and restore their worship
questions.explanation: Verses 12-13 promise that God will gather the children of Israel from Egypt and Assyria to worship Him in Jerusalem, offering hope and restoration for His scattered people (Isaiah 27:12, 27:13, 27:6).

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 27:5 teaches that making peace with God requires relying on His strength.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 27:5 states that one must take hold of God's strength to make peace with Him, emphasizing reliance on God's power for reconciliation.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 27:11 suggests that God will show mercy to those who lack understanding and continue in sin.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 27:11 explains that those who are a people of no understanding will not receive mercy from the one who made and formed them, highlighting the importance of repentance and understanding.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 27:2-3 teach about spiritual discipline and personal devotion?
options: God diligently cares for His people like a vineyard, requiring continual nurture
Spiritual discipline is unnecessary because God does everything
God abandons His vineyard to chance
Devotion is only needed in public worship
questions.correctAnswer: God diligently cares for His people like a vineyard, requiring continual nurture
questions.explanation: Verses 2-3 compare God's people to a vineyard that He continually waters and protects, teaching that spiritual growth requires ongoing care and discipline (Isaiah 27:2, 27:3, 27:6).

questions.question: A believer is discouraged by trials and setbacks. What does Isaiah 27:8 teach about perseverance?
options: God controls winds and trials, allowing them only in measure and timing
Believers face trials without God's involvement
All hardships are punishment without purpose
questions.correctAnswer: God controls winds and trials, allowing them only in measure and timing
questions.explanation: Isaiah 27:8 shows God’s control over the east wind and trials, teaching believers to trust God’s timing and moderation in difficulties for perseverance (Isaiah 27:8, 27:4, 27:5).

questions.question: Based on Isaiah 27:10-11, what warning does the passage give about ignoring God's guidance?
options: Ignoring God leads to desolation and destruction without mercy
God always shows mercy regardless of actions
Ignoring God results in immediate blessings
questions.correctAnswer: Ignoring God leads to desolation and destruction without mercy
questions.explanation: Verses 10-11 warn that those who reject God’s understanding become like a desolate city, subject to destruction without mercy, emphasizing the importance of obedience (Isaiah 27:10, 27:11, 27:9).

questions.question: How does Isaiah 27:13 encourage believers in their role of evangelism and worship?
options: The trumpet will call the scattered to worship God in Jerusalem, uniting believers
Worship is only individual and private
Evangelism is unnecessary because all are already saved
questions.correctAnswer: The trumpet will call the scattered to worship God in Jerusalem, uniting believers
questions.explanation: Verse 13 describes a future gathering where God’s people from various lands come together to worship, encouraging believers to participate in evangelism and corporate worship (Isaiah 27:13, 27:12, 27:6).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Isaiah 27:1 says the LORD will punish ______, the piercing serpent.
questions.correctAnswer: leviathan
questions.explanation: Isaiah 27:1 specifically names 'leviathan' as the piercing serpent whom the LORD will punish and slay, symbolizing God's power over evil.

questions.question: A believer feels overwhelmed by sin and guilt. According to Isaiah 27:9, what hope can you share about God's forgiveness?
options: God purges iniquity and removes sin through His judgment
God ignores sin and allows it to remain
questions.correctAnswer: God purges iniquity and removes sin through His judgment
questions.explanation: Isaiah 27:9 teaches that God's purging of iniquity removes sin, symbolized by breaking altar stones, giving hope for forgiveness and cleansing (Isaiah 27:9, 27:1, 27:13).

questions.question: How does Isaiah 27:5 encourage believers to seek peace with God in their daily walk?
options: By taking hold of God's strength, they can make peace with Him
Peace with God comes through personal effort alone
Peace is impossible without worldly success
Believers should avoid God to find peace
questions.correctAnswer: By taking hold of God's strength, they can make peace with Him
questions.explanation: Verse 5 emphasizes the need to rely on God's strength to establish peace with Him, encouraging humility and dependence on God in daily life (Isaiah 27:5, 27:4, 27:6).

hard.title: Isaiah Chapter 27 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Isaiah Chapter 27.

questions.question: In Isaiah 27:1, the LORD is said to punish Leviathan, described as a "piercing serpent" and a "crooked serpent." What is the symbolic significance of Leviathan in this context within the ancient Near Eastern worldview?
options: An emblem of chaos and evil forces opposing God’s order
A literal sea creature threatening Israel’s shores
A representation of Egypt’s political power
A metaphor for the Babylonian empire
questions.correctAnswer: An emblem of chaos and evil forces opposing God’s order
questions.explanation: Isaiah 27:1 uses Leviathan as a symbol of chaos and evil, common in ancient Near Eastern mythology, representing forces God will decisively defeat to establish order.

questions.question: Isaiah 27:2 uses the image of a vineyard of red wine. What is the literary purpose of this vineyard metaphor in the context of Israel’s restoration?
options: To signify Israel’s fruitful and cultivated land
To indicate the abundance of wine exports
To symbolize Israel as a people cultivated by God for blessing
To describe the agricultural economy of ancient Judah
questions.correctAnswer: To symbolize Israel as a people cultivated by God for blessing
questions.explanation: The vineyard metaphor in Isaiah 27:2 symbolizes Israel being carefully tended by God, reflecting themes of cultivation and divine care leading to blessing.

questions.question: In Isaiah 27:3, the LORD promises to water the vineyard every moment, keeping it night and day. How does this continuous care reflect the theological concept of God’s providence?
options: It emphasizes God’s unceasing protection and sustenance over His people
It means God controls the weather cycles literally
It refers only to agricultural irrigation practices
It highlights the priests’ role in temple rituals
questions.correctAnswer: It emphasizes God’s unceasing protection and sustenance over His people
questions.explanation: Isaiah 27:3 depicts God’s providence as constant and vigilant, ensuring the well-being and protection of His people continuously.

questions.question: Isaiah 27:4 states, "Fury is not in me." How does this declaration contrast with typical ancient Near Eastern depictions of gods and war?
options: It presents YHWH as a God of peace rather than wrathful battle
It shows YHWH’s weakness compared to other gods
It means YHWH will not participate in wars
It denies any divine anger altogether
questions.correctAnswer: It presents YHWH as a God of peace rather than wrathful battle
questions.explanation: Isaiah 27:4 contrasts YHWH’s character with warlike deities by emphasizing His peaceful nature despite possessing strength.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 27:5, what is the condition for making peace with the LORD?
questions.correctAnswer: Taking hold of His strength
questions.explanation: Isaiah 27:5 specifies that peace with the LORD is achieved by relying on His strength, emphasizing dependence on divine power for reconciliation.

questions.question: Isaiah 27:6 states that Israel shall "blossom and bud, and fill the face of the world with fruit." How does this eschatological promise connect with the Abrahamic covenant in Genesis?
options: It fulfills the promise of descendants and blessing to all nations
It contradicts the covenant by focusing on land only
It refers only to agricultural prosperity in Judah
It is unrelated to the covenant
questions.correctAnswer: It fulfills the promise of descendants and blessing to all nations
questions.explanation: The blossoming and fruitfulness in Isaiah 27:6 echoes God’s covenant with Abraham promising numerous descendants and blessings extending to the whole world (Genesis 12:2-3).

questions.question: In Isaiah 27:7, the rhetorical questions ask if Israel has been smitten as those who smote it. What literary device is primarily used here, and what is its purpose?
options: Rhetorical question to provoke reflection on injustice
Simile to compare Israel to other nations
Metaphor to depict Israel as a warrior
questions.correctAnswer: Rhetorical question to provoke reflection on injustice
questions.explanation: Isaiah 27:7 employs rhetorical questions to highlight the unfairness of Israel’s punishment compared to its enemies, encouraging readers to consider divine justice.

questions.question: Isaiah 27:8 mentions "debating" with the shoot and staying the rough wind in the day of the east wind. What might the 'east wind' symbolize in the ancient Hebrew context?
options: A destructive force or judgment from God
questions.correctAnswer: A destructive force or judgment from God
questions.explanation: The east wind in Hebrew literature often symbolizes a harsh, destructive force (e.g., Exodus 10:13), and Isaiah 27:8 uses it to represent adversity restrained by God.

questions.question: Isaiah 27:9 speaks about purging the iniquity of Jacob and destroying altars, groves, and images. How does this purification relate to the Deuteronomic reforms found in 2 Kings 18-19?
options: It echoes the removal of idolatry and centralized worship in Jerusalem
It contradicts the reforms by allowing altars
It focuses solely on foreign idols, not Israelite worship
It calls for more altars to be built
questions.correctAnswer: It echoes the removal of idolatry and centralized worship in Jerusalem
questions.explanation: Isaiah 27:9’s call to destroy altars and images parallels the Deuteronomic reforms under King Hezekiah which centralized worship and eliminated idolatry (2 Kings 18-19).

questions.question: Isaiah 27:10 describes a "defenced city" becoming desolate and a calf feeding there. What does this imagery likely symbolize in the prophetic critique?
options: The failure of false security and idolatry leading to desolation
The prosperity of cities relying on agriculture
The protection of Israel by its cities
The strength of Israel’s military defenses
questions.correctAnswer: The failure of false security and idolatry leading to desolation
questions.explanation: The desolate city and feeding calf in Isaiah 27:10 symbolize the futility of relying on false security and idolatry, resulting in ruin and abandonment.

questions.question: In Isaiah 27:11, the people are described as "a people of no understanding" who face no mercy. How does this relate to the covenantal theme of obedience and consequence?
options: It underscores that lack of understanding leads to judgment without mercy
It suggests God’s mercy is unconditional
It means only foreigners are judged
It indicates that understanding is irrelevant to covenant
questions.correctAnswer: It underscores that lack of understanding leads to judgment without mercy
questions.explanation: Isaiah 27:11 links disobedience and lack of understanding to divine judgment, aligning with covenant themes where obedience results in blessing and disobedience in punishment.

questions.question: Isaiah 27:12 speaks of the LORD beating off from the channel of the river to the stream of Egypt and gathering Israel one by one. What historical event might this prophecy foreshadow?
options: The return of the exiles from Assyria and Egypt
The crossing of the Red Sea during the Exodus
The invasion of Egypt by Babylon
questions.correctAnswer: The return of the exiles from Assyria and Egypt
questions.explanation: Isaiah 27:12 foreshadows the regathering of Israelite exiles from foreign lands such as Assyria and Egypt, a theme of restoration after captivity.

questions.question: Isaiah 27:13 mentions the blowing of a great trumpet and coming to worship on the holy mount at Jerusalem. Which New Testament event is often connected typologically to this trumpet sound?
options: The resurrection and rapture at the last trumpet (1 Corinthians 15:52)
The Pentecost outpouring of the Spirit
questions.correctAnswer: The resurrection and rapture at the last trumpet (1 Corinthians 15:52)
questions.explanation: The trumpet in Isaiah 27:13 is typologically linked to the 'last trumpet' in 1 Corinthians 15:52, symbolizing resurrection and gathering of God’s people.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 27:1 indicates that the LORD will use a 'sore and great and strong sword' to bring judgment against Leviathan.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 27:1 explicitly states the LORD will punish Leviathan with a 'sore and great and strong sword,' indicating divine judgment by force.

questions.question: True or False: According to Isaiah 27:4, the LORD expresses fury and declares He will burn the briers and thorns in battle against them.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 27:4 states 'Fury is not in me,' indicating the LORD does not harbor fury, though He would burn briers and thorns if challenged, showing restraint rather than wrathfulness.

theological.title: Isaiah Chapter 27 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Isaiah Chapter 27 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 27:1, who will the LORD punish with His strong and great sword?
questions.correctAnswer: Leviathan the piercing serpent
questions.explanation: Isaiah 27:1 clearly states that the LORD will punish Leviathan, described as a piercing and crooked serpent, and slay the dragon in the sea. This symbolizes God's judgment over chaotic evil forces (cf. Job 41; Psalm 74:14; Revelation 20:2; Psalm 104:26).

questions.question: In Isaiah 27:2, what is the vineyard compared to that the people are commanded to sing unto?
questions.correctAnswer: A vineyard of red wine
questions.explanation: Isaiah 27:2 uses the metaphor of a vineyard of red wine, symbolizing Israel or God's people, for whom praise and care are commanded. This reflects God’s covenantal relationship with His people (cf. Psalm 80:8; John 15:1-5; Isaiah 5:1-7; Romans 11:17-24).

questions.question: What does the LORD promise to do for the vineyard in Isaiah 27:3?
options: Keep it and water it every moment
Let it be destroyed by enemies
questions.correctAnswer: Keep it and water it every moment
questions.explanation: Isaiah 27:3 affirms God’s protective care over His people, likening them to a vineyard He keeps and waters continuously. This reflects God's providential and sustaining grace (cf. Psalm 23:1-3; Jeremiah 31:3; John 10:28; Hebrews 13:5).

questions.question: According to Isaiah 27:4, what is not in the LORD, and what would He do against briers and thorns?
options: Fury is not in Him; He would burn them together
Anger is in Him; He would destroy everything
Jealousy is in Him; He would hide Himself
Hatred is in Him; He would abandon them
questions.correctAnswer: Fury is not in Him; He would burn them together
questions.explanation: Isaiah 27:4 states that fury is not in the LORD, and if He were to contend with briers and thorns, He would burn them together. This demonstrates God's patience and righteous judgment (cf. James 1:20; Psalm 37:8; Romans 12:19; Nahum 1:3).

questions.question: What is the condition mentioned in Isaiah 27:5 for making peace with the LORD?
questions.correctAnswer: Taking hold of His strength
questions.explanation: Isaiah 27:5 says that one must take hold of the LORD’s strength to make peace with Him, emphasizing reliance on God's power for reconciliation (cf. Psalm 18:2; Isaiah 41:10; Ephesians 6:10; Philippians 4:13).

questions.question: What will Israel do according to Isaiah 27:6 when they take root?
options: Blossom, bud, and fill the world with fruit
questions.correctAnswer: Blossom, bud, and fill the world with fruit
questions.explanation: Isaiah 27:6 promises that Israel will blossom, bud, and fill the face of the world with fruit, symbolizing spiritual renewal and blessing (cf. Psalm 1:3; Jeremiah 17:7-8; John 15:5; Galatians 5:22-23).

questions.question: According to Isaiah 27:7, what question is raised about how Israel suffers compared to others?
options: Has he been smitten as those who smote him?
questions.correctAnswer: Has he been smitten as those who smote him?
questions.explanation: Isaiah 27:7 questions whether Israel has been smitten like those who smote them or slain as their enemies were slain, reflecting on divine justice and suffering (cf. Psalm 44:22; Isaiah 53:4-5; Romans 8:18; 2 Corinthians 1:5).

questions.question: What is described in Isaiah 27:9 as the way Jacob’s iniquity will be purged?
options: Making altar stones as chalkstones and destroying groves and images
questions.correctAnswer: Making altar stones as chalkstones and destroying groves and images
questions.explanation: Isaiah 27:9 explains that Jacob’s sin will be taken away by making altar stones as chalkstones and destroying groves and images, symbolizing the removal of idolatry and true repentance (cf. Deuteronomy 12:3; Psalm 51:16-17; Jeremiah 10:3-4; 1 Corinthians 6:9-11).

questions.question: What will happen to the defenced city according to Isaiah 27:10?
options: It shall be desolate and like a wilderness
It will become a place of refuge
questions.correctAnswer: It shall be desolate and like a wilderness
questions.explanation: Isaiah 27:10 describes the defenced city becoming desolate and forsaken, symbolizing judgment upon unfaithfulness (cf. Lamentations 5:17; Ezekiel 26:14; Matthew 23:38; Revelation 18:2).

questions.question: Why does Isaiah 27:11 say that those who set fire to the boughs are a people of no understanding?
options: Because God will show them no mercy or favor
Because they are wise in their own eyes
Because they seek peace with God
questions.correctAnswer: Because God will show them no mercy or favor
questions.explanation: Isaiah 27:11 states that the people who set the boughs on fire are without understanding, leading to God withholding mercy and favor, highlighting the consequences of persistent rebellion (cf. Proverbs 1:7; Romans 1:21-22; Hebrews 10:26-29; Ezekiel 33:13).

questions.question: In Isaiah 27:12, from where will the LORD gather the children of Israel?
options: From the channel of the river to the stream of Egypt
From the ends of the earth
questions.correctAnswer: From the channel of the river to the stream of Egypt
questions.explanation: Isaiah 27:12 states the LORD will gather Israel from the channel of the river (Euphrates) to the stream of Egypt, indicating a comprehensive regathering of the scattered people (cf. Ezekiel 37:21-22; Jeremiah 23:3; Amos 9:14; John 11:52).

questions.question: What event is described in Isaiah 27:13 involving a great trumpet?
options: The gathering of the outcasts to worship the LORD in Jerusalem
The destruction of the enemies of Israel
The beginning of the harvest season
questions.correctAnswer: The gathering of the outcasts to worship the LORD in Jerusalem
questions.explanation: Isaiah 27:13 depicts a future day when a great trumpet will sound, gathering those ready to perish from Assyria and Egypt to worship the LORD on the holy mount at Jerusalem, an eschatological gathering (cf. Joel 2:1; 1 Corinthians 15:52; Matthew 24:31; Hebrews 12:22).

questions.question: How does Isaiah 27:8 describe the response to the shoot when it shoots forth?
options: Debate with it and stay the rough wind in the day of the east wind
questions.correctAnswer: Debate with it and stay the rough wind in the day of the east wind
questions.explanation: Isaiah 27:8 uses agricultural imagery of debating with the shoot and restraining the harsh east wind, symbolizing God’s control over judgment and growth (cf. Hosea 6:2; Psalm 1:3; James 5:7; Revelation 11:3).

questions.question: What does the LORD say about fury in Himself in Isaiah 27:4?
options: Fury leads Me to punish without mercy
questions.correctAnswer: Fury is not in Me
questions.explanation: Isaiah 27:4 declares that fury is not in the LORD, highlighting God's patience and sovereign control even in judgment (cf. Exodus 34:6; Psalm 103:8; 2 Peter 3:9; Lamentations 3:22-23).

questions.question: According to Isaiah 27:9, what will not stand up after the iniquity of Jacob is purged?
questions.correctAnswer: Groves and images
questions.explanation: Isaiah 27:9 states that after Jacob's sin is purged, groves and images (idols) will not stand, indicating the destruction of idolatry and false worship (cf. Deuteronomy 7:5; Psalm 115:4-8; Jeremiah 10:14; 1 John 5:21).
